Despite the apparent cultural differences between islanders and people from the west, Hofschnieder’s journey of migration and isolation, of moving alone from a small, remote town to a hustling city, felt in line with the cowboy experience.“I don’t see myself as a cowgirl, obviously, but him phrasing it that way made me realize there have been many moments in my life where I was wandering alone,” Hofschneider said.This was McGarrigle’s second workshop, but his first time reading a poem. “I didn’t perform because I was almost intimidated by so many cowboy hats and thinking that I didn’t belong, and I’m a poser,” he explained. “But Amir and Zane do such a good job of reassuring the crowd by saying, even though the theme is cowboy poetry, it’s just about getting up on stage.”View image in fullscreen‘Being a cowboy, it’s not what you do, but who you are and how you respect yourself, others and the land.’Katie Meza, who attended her first workshop in August, also felt that Beardsley and York quickly embraced her.“I’ve never touched a horse in my life, but we all get to appreciate the culture equally,” Meza said.She came to the August eventwith her ex-boyfriend, Michael Salonius, 51, an elk rancher from Crescent City, Oregon. The 13th-generation mountaineer grew up hearing cowboy poetry in his hometown bar, and was excited when he discovered the event through Instagram. He was bracing for a dingy room with just a handful of old men, and was shocked by the young, energetic crowd.“It exceeded my expectations,” Salonius said. “To see this many young people doing it, taking it seriously, and the diversity of poems … ” He trailed off, then cracked a wide smile. “It’s fucking rad,” he said.Towards the end of that night, Jarod Ramirez, 25, took the stage. He grew up in Hesperia, a town surrounded by the Mojave desert, and said the workshop was helping him reconnect to his roots. His grandfather was born in New Mexico, and Ramirez remembered him as the embodiment of a western lifestyle. He sported his grandfather’s old silver bolo tie, which was in the shape of a bean and embedded with red and blue turquoise stones.“This is my first time doing cowboy poetry, so we’ll see if it’s good or not,” Ramirez said, then launched into An Ode to the Hatch Chili:Green or redthe favorite color can end in a brawl.But you’re more subtle than that.If asked, I’d say green,if one appreciates the color of cacti and spikes of Joshua trees,red if you’re hot-blooded and savor the sunset.But what is it that makes you so special?Being of Old Mexico. I’ve had my fair share of spicesbut my New Mexican familyhad some kind of magic.They capture the taste of a wild desert, fire,and put it on the top of my tongue.The audience loudly clapped and cheered. With that, Ramirez was on his way to becoming a cowboy poet; all he needs to do is write, be kind and nurture his appreciation for the west.“I like to tell folks being a cowboy, it’s not what you do, but who you are and how you respect yourself, others and the land,” Beardsley said.Explore more on these topicsCaliforniaPoetryWesternsWest CoastfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: When a heart attack left me in a coma, my hallucinations inspired a novel – and a new life | Books | The Guardian
description: After his heart stopped beating for 40 minutes, the former lawyer experienced weeks of hallucinations. The visions he experienced during his recovery set him on the path to a new career
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: After his heart stopped beating for 40 minutes, the former lawyer experienced weeks of hallucinations. The visions he experienced during his recovery set him on the path to a new career
Content: ‘I am alive, I can see and I can write’ … Patrick Charnley.Photograph: Jesse AlexanderView image in fullscreen‘I am alive, I can see and I can write’ … Patrick Charnley.Photograph: Jesse AlexanderBooksWhen a heart attack left me in a coma, my hallucinations inspired a novel – and a new lifeAfter his heart stopped beating for 40 minutes, the former lawyer experienced weeks of hallucinations. The visions he experienced during his recovery set him on the path to a new careerPatrick CharnleySun 4 Jan 2026 11.00 ESTShareOn the evening of Monday 1 February 2021, during the third Covid lockdown, my wife Alexa and I sat down on the sofa to have sausages and chips in front of the TV. The children were tetchy, and we were worn out from trying to home-school them while working from home, me as a lawyer in the music industry and Alexa as a charity fundraiser. But at least, Alexa said to me, we had made it through January.Then I started making strange noises. “Are you joking?” she asked. Then, “are you choking?”She knew it was my heart. Days before, my cardiologist had told me I would need surgery within the next six months to repair a leaking valve that had been getting progressively worse for years.“What if you don’t have the surgery?” Alexa had asked. I replied: “I’ll just drop down dead.” I was joking – my heart problem wasn’t thought to be  that serious – but as it turned out, I was right. By the time my dinner tray started slipping from my lap to the floor, I was already clinically dead. My heart had stopped beating and I wasn’t breathing. I was having a cardiac arrest.I am alive now only because of my wife and son who got help, my friend and neighbour Peter who gave me cardiopulmonary resuscitation, and the paramedics who eventually got my heart started again – 40 minutes after I had stopped breathing.I was taken to hospital in a state of deep unconsciousness, leaving Alexa standing in our living room, where the furniture had been pushed aside and there was mud on the floor and debris from the paramedics’ equipment strewn everywhere.It would be two months before I’d return home, visually impaired and with a brain injury, my perspective on life altered completely.Part of my brain had been turned off; I only experienced sensations not thoughts – it was like the silence after a crashThe days after my cardiac arrest were a time of total contrast: Alexa was living a nightmare, not knowing whether I would live or die, while I was in a coma, oblivious to what was happening.Then, on Friday, I woke up. The hospital set up a video call for me to talk to Alexa, but I was making no sense. The following day, it became clear that I was blind. That’s when the doctors started talking to Alexa about a brain injury caused by the lack of oxygen, and her relief at me having survived turned into a sense of dread about what this might mean.A few days later, Alexa was allowed to visit me in the hospital as an exception to the lockdown rules; the doctors thought it could help me as I was so confused and disoriented. I was also hallucinating. When she arrived, I had just had a brain scan, and when she asked me about it, I told her I had been to a premiere of a film about bees.Over the coming days, when Alexa wasn’t visiting, we would video call a lot. She says I was laughing and joking as if I was hosting a dinner party, completely unaware of what had happened. She, the doctors and the nurses would tell me time and again that I’d had a cardiac arrest and that I had a brain injury, but I would immediately forget anything that I’d been told.Weeks later in neurological rehab, I underwent extensive testing which found my memory and other cognitive functions were in the bottom 2% of the population. One day in hospital I asked why my mother hadn’t been to visit, and Alexa had to tell me that she had died three years before.During the second week, my sight began to return, but only partially and I had trouble processing what I was seeing. I remember sitting by the hospital window one day, feeling cold air seeping through the window frames, craving a breath of it. It had snowed overnight, and I was looking out at Hampstead Heath, unable to understand why it was white.Throughout this time, the hallucinations – caused by the brain trying to compensate for my loss of vision – continued. One had a significant impact on me, and really my novel,This, My Second Life,came from it.In it, I was in a cottage hospital in Dublin, some time in the past. I was alone in bed in a small dark room. The door was ajar and outside a group of young nurses with lilting Irish accents were sitting round a table in the soft glow of an oil lamp, talking very quietly. Murmuring, really. I felt so looked after, like nothing could possibly hurt me, and it had a profound effect on me.I believe I had that hallucination because I was being looked after like that in real life. I still remember and am grateful for the extreme kindness of the doctors and nurses and other people working at the hospitals I stayed in, and those who have cared for me since.Around that time, I felt as a baby with a belly full of milk must feel: content and untouched by the world. Before, I’d been trying to balance a stressful job with lockdown and home schooling. Now I just sat or lay for hours without thinking about anything, floating through time. The busy part of my brain had been turned off, and all I experienced were sensations, not thoughts. It was like the silence after a monumental crash.When I returned home from hospital, I wanted to hold on to this feeling, to record it, and I began to write. I can see now that with my writing I was creating a world that reflected the tranquillity that I was experiencing. I was building a sanctuary that I could go to for that sensation of total peace.I remember a hot day, lying outdoors and writing in my notebook. I carried on like this, writing small amounts by hand, once every few days, often forgetting what I had written before, and hampered also by dyslexia and extreme fatigue from the brain injury.I see the world differently now – although I am more limited in what I can do, my life feels freerAs I wrote slowly over the next three years, I came to realise how fundamentally my experience had changed me. I see the world differently now, and although I am very limited in what I can do compared with before, my life feels freer and more open.It was important to me to have a connection to the work of my late mother, the writer Helen Dunmore. My main character is called Jago, the name of the young boy in a picture book my mother and I worked on together years ago. I also reincarnated the character of Granny Carne from my mother’s Cornish Ingo books, a wise woman as old as the hills who helps Jago adjust to his life after suffering the same health crisis as me. So, although I can’t tell my mother about my book, I am happy that there is a thread through time connecting her work to mine.When I finished writing the novel, I put it away and didn’t do anything with it. Trying to publish it would have been a step too far back into the world.But I also knew that I needed more from life than just drifting through, that I had a second chance, so I sent my novel out. When I was offered a publishing deal for it, I felt as if I was being given a new start, and I understood that writing is what I will do.In a way, This, My Second Life is not only about Jago’s second life, but about mine too. I have a lot of problems, but I am alive, I can see, I have my family and friends, and I can write. My greatest hope for my novel is that it leaves readers feeling uplifted and with the sense of peace, contentment and possibility that it has given to me.This, My Second Life by Patrick Charnley is published by Hutchinson Heinemann. title: Kindness of strangers: I was ill and about to miss my flight when a well-dressed man helped me to the airport | Australian lifestyle | The Guardian
description: I was running an hour late and couldn’t think straight. I was in despair that I might miss my plane home
Author: Katie Cunningham
Headline: I was running an hour late and couldn’t think straight. I was in despair that I might miss my plane home
Content: ‘The gentleman wouldn’t let me pay for the fare, and even hopped out to escort me inside the terminal … I felt overwhelmed with gratitude.’Illustration: Victoria Hart/Guardian Design/AlamyView image in fullscreen‘The gentleman wouldn’t let me pay for the fare, and even hopped out to escort me inside the terminal … I felt overwhelmed with gratitude.’Illustration: Victoria Hart/Guardian Design/AlamyKindness of strangersAustralian lifestyleKindness of strangers: I was ill and about to miss my flight when a well-dressed man helped me to the airportI was running an hour late and couldn’t think clearly. I was in despair that I might miss my plane homeRead more in thekindness of strangers seriesAnonymous, as told toKatie CunninghamSun 4 Jan 2026 09.00 ESTLast modified on Sun 4 Jan 2026 17.52 ESTShareTwelve years ago, I was in Queanbeyan to see a specialist for my chronic health condition. I was headed home to Queensland early the next morning and had set my alarm to wake me for the taxi I had ordered to the airport. But when I woke up, I realised that I had forgotten to allow for daylight savings. I was now running an hour late to the airport, with no taxi to get me there.I ordered another taxi and made my way out to wait in front of the motel, in despair that I might miss my flight. I stood on the dark footpath and spoke on the phone to my sister in Queensland about how I had missed my taxi and how unwell I felt. My health condition can affect my ability to think clearly, and I was telling her how my brain just wasn’t working that day. Then the taxi arrived – phew. Except, as the driver told me when I opened the door to get in, it wasn’t for me.The kindness of strangers: a boy picked up my spilled shopping when I was too pregnant to reach the groundRead moreA well-dressed, professional-appearing man appeared out of the shadows and stood beside me. He must have overheard my conversation. The taxi was for him, but he asked the driver to take me too.I gratefully got in and, in conversation, explained my situation to the man and driver, who were both very kind. At one point, the man said something to the driver, but I didn’t hear what. I noticed later that we were on the way to the airport and realised the gentleman had asked the driver not to drop him off at his destination, but to take me to the airport first. I tried to object but the man wouldn’t hear of it.When we arrived, the gentleman wouldn’t let me pay for the fare, and even hopped out to escort me inside the terminal and make sure I knew where to go and what to do. I felt overwhelmed with gratitude.When you have a chronic health condition like mine, it can be an invisible illness. People tell me they wouldn’t know there’s anything wrong just from looking at me. It means you don’t always get empathy from people when you don’t feel well, but that man was all empathy.I intended to write to a local newspaper to thank him at the time, but I became less well again and it fell to the back of my mind. I’m hoping he sees this now, after all these years. So to that well-dressed gentleman: thank you for being kind when so many others aren’t. Words can’t match the difference you made to my day.What is the nicest thing a stranger has ever done for you?Share your experienceWhat's the nicest thing a stranger has ever done for you?From making your day to changing your life, we want to hear about  chance encounters that have stuck with you.Please share your story if you are 18 or over, anonymously if you wish. title: Readers reply: should we turn the internet off? | Life and style | The Guardian
description: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions ponders the online world – from what’s despicable to what’s indispensable
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions ponders the online world – from what’s despicable to what’s indispensable
Content: Was the old-tech world a better one? Who would turn back the clock?Photograph: Kirill Ikonnikov/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenWas the old-tech world a better one? Who would turn back the clock?Photograph: Kirill Ikonnikov/Getty ImagesNotes and queriesLife and styleReaders reply: should we turn the internet off?The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions ponders the online world – from what’s despicable to what’s indispensableThis week’s question: can you really fake it to make it?Sun 4 Jan 2026 09.00 ESTLast modified on Sun 4 Jan 2026 09.03 ESTShareThe internet has turned fringe belief into mainstream politics and policy – from authoritarianism to vaccines. With democracy itself threatened, is it time to go back to a previous world of landlines, letters and face to-face-contact, audiotapes and Ansaphones? What would we miss about the online world that is worth the risk to liberal culture and basic freedoms? Should we turn the internet off?Mees Visser, Groningen, the NetherlandsSend new questions tonq@theguardian.com.Readers reply“I can’t let you do that Dave.”LandofsanderYes. We did just fine before it came along.Michael York, by emailBit late now.GoldgreenReading a newspaper from around the world. I am about to do my grocery shopping online. I am messaging family on the other side of the Atlantic. And you want me to turn that off? The problem isn’t the internet, it’s the people.1EloiseAccording to Google’s AI Overview: “Come and have a go if you think you’re hard enough.”EddieChorepostWithout Google Maps I would probably still be walking in circles in the middle of Epping Forest.1AngryManThanks to Google maps, Iamwalking in circles in the middle of Epping Forest!!Doomxsfsddgvhyt)I won’t be the first to point out what the internet has offered to disabled people. It’s a place where someone I know, who finds speaking nearly impossible due to physical challenges, can be fluent, authoritative and, most importantly, properly listened to at last. And that’s just one example. It’s not for me or anyone else to take that away. I actually hate web 2.0 with a passion and for any number of reasons, but I can’t refute this point, nor would I seek to.AsureaHonestly, without the internet I would be isolated and alone. I have a conservative family and am in the closet and queer and trans. With the internet my world finally expanded and I finally became free. I learned about myself and became happy and at peace. I met my most important person after a lifetime of difficulty connecting to people and I found things I loved that changed me. The internet has done a lot of harm, yes, but it’s not black and white and has been a lifeline for queer and disabled folk such as myself. I am so grateful for the connection and friendship I found thanks to the internet.Kati777The internet itself is a magnificent technological achievement, not a moral failure. It has democratised access to knowledge, lowered barriers to publishing, connected marginal voices and transformed education, science and culture in ways that are hard to overstate.The problem is not “the internet” so much as the concentration of power in a handful of social media platforms that algorithmically amplify outrage, misinformation and fringe belief while disclaiming responsibility for the consequences.Most of the damage could be addressed by treating these companies as accountable intermediaries rather than neutral pipes: enforcing transparency around amplification, meaningful liability for harm, and standards closer to those long applied to publishers and broadcasters.Rolling back to landlines and letters would mean losing real, hard-won freedoms. The challenge is not to abandon the online world, but to civilise it.littlewasterPlease God yes. However nice and convenient it is to book a train ticket or transfer money from my bank account, none of it compensates for the breakdown in society which is occurring because of what is now a malignant online world.Kirsty McNally, by emailI don’t know anybody who thinks society has improved in the last 30 years. I miss how fun and open-minded we used to be, and I miss being engaged with the real world, in all my time awake on this planet. Is there any chance of this actually happening? I hope so.Peter Rizzo, by emailShould we turn radio off? Should we turn newspapers off? Should we turn the printing press off? And books? Should we turn off writing on paper and drawing on cave walls? These questions were probably all raised by someone, not very long after those respective inventions escaped the control of their inventors. Each time, the previous elite lost control to the masses over information and discourse, history keeps repeating.Randomusername222No. We would miss that which is a deeply embedded and nearly indispensable need of humanity – connection. The internet allows us to quickly engage with other humans (around the planet!), which could be a lifesaver for those of us who cannot find community and acceptance in our immediate surroundings.In being able to share our experiences we can galvanise opinion to push for change (I’m thinking of the murder of George Floyd and following outrage, and also that in an era before the internet, it was through the sharing of images of brutalised peaceful protesters for racial equality in the American south that the country was shamed into reform).The internet enables sharing in a way unprecedented in human existence; it is this ability to join minds and hearts, sometimes across all known and artificial divisions that helps us find ourselves as individuals and communities, nations, and maybe one day as a planet.Henry Thorpe, by emailView image in fullscreenHappier days or a time of limited contact?Photograph: H Armstrong Roberts/ClassicStockThe internet is a communication medium, it is not the communication itself. Blaming “the internet” is like blaming the post office if you get a nasty letter. Turning off the internet would be like turning off mains electricity, or banning road transport other than horses.You can’t turn the clock back. There was no long-lost golden age.DopFnordMy job in IT heavily depends on it. Outside my job, I’ve deleted all social media apps from my phone. It’s been quite a liberating experience. That whole realm has been hijacked and I find it worrying how many people use it as their primary source of news and information. Thankfully this paper seems to be one of the few places of resistance.AyJayEmObviously it’s far too late to put the genie back in the lamp (perhaps a more accurate metaphor would be to unwet the mogwai), but I often find myself wishing we could roll things back to just before the invention of the smartphone. That way, we’d still have most of the benefits of the internet, but it would be contained within a bulky device that lived in the corner of a room in our homes and on our desks at work. We’d be able to turn our backs on it whenever we left the house or office, and we wouldn’t be obliged to carry it with us all the time (I know in most cases we’re not “obliged” to carry smartphones with us, but it takes tremendous strength of will to swim against the tide all the time, not to mention how difficult many organisations make it to do things offline).To me, that seems like a pretty good balance between enjoying the advantages of the internet while preserving those priceless and eminently human aspects of our lives that the internet has done a great deal to damage, if not outright destroyed.SignedUpToWriteThisThe best option is to use the internet in moderation and never to switch off your brain.willemijnheidemanThere is nothing on the internet that does not leave a digital footprint. Governments could so simply make “social media” responsible for the accuracy of what they publish, in the same way that a newspaper is responsible. If they can be sued, they will control the crazy people spouting lies. Make them responsible. Sanction their owners. China and Russia control the internet. It can be done.CynicalGeorgeIf anything, this article and comments has shown me that a huge amount of Guardian readers don’t know what the internet is or what aspects of modern life would be affected by “turning it off” (nearly everything, most likely from the power grid on up).unhelpfulThe question poses “the internet” as both the root cause of that which ails modern society and as the antithesis of liberalism and human freedom. This is, of course, leading the witness. The internet is not designed to respect geographical borders. Its technology is not free of political bias, though having been devised in the US that bias is towards the modern western conceptions of freedom that the writer holds in such high regard.The former GDR (East Germany) managed breathtaking levels of landline tapping and turning family members against one another. Conversations were frequently recorded. I do not see how a return to exclusively in-person contact, cassette tapes and landlines would intrinsically benefit those of us who value freedom.The internet is designed to be flexible, scalable and open at distance. The openness that doesn’t respect traditional notions of borders is the same openness that allows states to use marvellous technologies against their own populations, because here’s what governments understand: people want to feel connected to one another, those connections can threaten thestatus quo,ergothose connections need to be coralled and controlled.People and organisations campaigning for freedom have long gathered and communicated using the internet, predating by many years the modern “walled gardens” of social media. Those voices are still here and there and everywhere. Perhaps, if you step away from the noise of everyone shouting into the void, you’ll be able to discern them talking about running the world in a different way.DorkaliciousI have mobility issues, yet I’ve managed to do all my Christmas present shopping without leaving the house. I designed our Christmas card and uploaded the image to have it printed. We’ve just had a big food shop delivered.I can see via the NHS app on my phone that a prescription I requested has been approved and sent to our local pharmacy. The pharmacy will text me when it’s ready. We have several FaceTime sessions planned with family and friends around the world.I make a lot of use of the internet. It’s simply a question of using it wisely.snowybeachI was diagnosed as a type 1 diabetic in the early 80s and it was an extremely isolating experience. I knew no one else with the condition and just had to deal with things very much alone. It’s so much better now for newly diagnosed children to be able to connect to others in a similar position.AucklandCanaryView image in fullscreenEverything except the dial-up modem … the way things, recently, were.Photograph: Phiwath Jittamas/Getty ImagesPeople confuse the internet, which is a communication tool, with the various platforms, social media included, that use it. There are a lot of incredibly useful, practical things we do on the internet that benefit us. Not everything is a social media swamp, something we can choose to engage with, or not.The internet is still in its infancy, so we’re at the proverbial wild west stage of its development with a host of crazies, carpetbaggers, extremists and entrepreneurs allowed pretty free rein, so it can be grim. Governments and political campaigners have both tried to exploit this “freedom” and also failed to manage it, partly because they don’t understand it, so it’s a bit of a cesspool.Add the likes of all the tech bros, and it gets even worse.Not all bad though. Enshittification is now well recognised and people are getting pissed off with it. The days when everyone believed what they read are going fast, too, ironically hastened by the growth of AI slop and the likes of Trump and Musk. There’s more open criticism of such slop, and a lot more questioning of what’s the truth and what propaganda. The platforms are run by wealthy rightwingers but even now, much of the discussion is about obvious propaganda, fake AI-generated shopfronts and content. I believe social media has started to lose its attraction for many people, with people posting and engaging less.Almost half of young people would prefer a world without internet, UK study findsRead moreThe internet doesn’t need to be turned off, it just needs to be better managed and, on a personal level, used more carefully and responsibly. It needs to grow up.DJT1MillionWe’re in the corporate capture stage of the internet, which is why the user interface for most people now consists of checking the same four apps over and over again, and posting the same content from one of them on to one or more of the other three.Being online is no longer really enjoyable, it’s merely compulsive behaviour orcompulsoryfor participating in society – and is frequently actively annoying and frustrating in proportion to what you get out of it.In its first decade the possibilities of the internet seemed democratic and limitless. Now it’s just another plaything and control mechanism of the Oligarchy.Frank_LynnFor many people in the world, the internet provides one of the few opportunities for girls to study. I imagine that would be missed.GUsername1Technology destroys people and places. I’m rejecting it | Mark BoyleRead moreI was about 32 when the internet became widely used, and I often struggle to recall how on earth I found things out. I read more actual books from cover to cover and my attention span was longer. I now struggle to focus for longer than a few minutes. I once used the phone a lot to book things, which meant having to speak to actual people more. Friends reunited was fairly innocent fun, but then Facebook was born, Snapchat, TikTok … .ChrisPookThere are conceptually simple enough solutions to the stink of the internet sewer. One is to forbid anonymity. All uploads to incorporate a source address.The other would be an even greater boon – to tax ads.nosuchzoneNo. But democracies will need to learn how to address misinformation to challenge the mobocracy. Besides, it still has so many positive and benign uses. As a musician, I would miss the ease with which new skills can be learned and ideas shared. I’m sure others will find reasons of their own for not wanting to turn the clock back.fender64Maybe a world internet-free day might be doable as a way of reflection on being too dependent on it. I will never forget that day in April in Spain when all the electricity went off and one couldn’t access the internet. People were much nicer to each other and helped one another out. You couldn’t access the news without a transistor radio and that wasn’t a bad thing.DaveTrollI’m sure I’ve read about surgeons who have to do something rare being able to get live expert guidance by video call. That’s potentially life-saving.HummusexualMeta just suspended my Facebook account, probably for reporting too many hate groups. So I guess that means less internet for me.TatrabantQuality of life was much better before the internet. People had time for each other, it was possible to understand and fix machines, and convenience was not dependent on accepting endless nastiness, fraud, and fascist adventuring as a fact of life.Digital processes are useful for research but have proved a disaster for human communication and now fuel criminality faster than the ability of law enforcement to contain them. Pull the plug and let us learn to live again.ElephantmothIt was different, but whether it was better depended on circumstances. Those people around the world who now have access to some form of education thanks to internet access might disagree with [turning it off].middle24Without the internet, I’d not have my job (engineer), my bachelor’s and master’s degrees, would’ve found it much harder to find my apartment and roommate, and couldn’t do most of my shopping online so would need to take longer and more frequent trips just to shop since I’ve chosen a car-free lifestyle.But I’m also only on one social network: Reddit, which allows me to read and interact with others about just the topics I select. I only enable notifications for things that actually matter on my phone. I’m also among the minority not staring down at my phone on a bus or train, partly because it gives me motion sickness. I also rarely wear headphones while out, due to preferring to tune into my environment or let my mind wander.So I think the problem is not the internet itself but how we use it. Many fall into the trap of semi-passive consumption of media, allowing those on the other side of that content to disproportionally influence their ideas and behaviors. Were more people wise and kind in their usage of the internet, that’s what would make it better.fr33_th1nk3rAviation is so integrated with the internet that there would be chaos at airports. If you consider that shutting down aviation at the same time would be a good thing, just consider how much food comes in to the UK by air freight, and how much gets exported the same way (Scottish whisky and salmon). There’d be chaos.SocialismnowMake everyone use their real names online. You get a single email address and a single “internet-wide” user account. That will solve most of your problems right there.allanbabb(Replied to byBristolBoy: “Unless you are a dissident in, say, Russia or China, of course”, and byDauGiHyfryd:“I wonder if some of us will, in a year or two, be taken to task for our currently legal posts in the UK.”)My answer is a resounding no. Although there are some areas of the internet which have become walled gardens of algorithms, AI slop and advertising, there are so many other areas where the spirit of the early internet lives on. One example is the “indieweb” where people amateurishly code their own websites, making public whatever content they want rather than staying within the bounds of media companies.The rise of the ‘indieweb’ also includes the resurgence of the email newsletter (or RSS feed if you like). Instead of scrolling on infinite social media feeds, I get my brain going with some thoughtfully written blog posts in my inbox, introducing me to perspectives I would never have come across in the offline world. Long live the indieweb!accidentalusernameYeah go on – let’s see what happens. More shops on the high street, more money spent locally. More social cohesion, interaction and tolerance?ForfrocksakesGibbonsThe grass is always greener. As with all things, the key is balance. The internet is a tool. It’s up to us collectively to make the most out of the tools we have. Unfortunately, the people power of the internet is increasingly owned by the topmost shareholders.KromenoidDid you try turning it off and then turning it back on again?DeusPascitCorvosWhy stop there? Why not go back to tribal hunter gatherer existence and wearing animal skins?Face it. Every era has its challenges and this one is no different. Turning off the internet is throwing the baby out with the bath water.krutThe ability to talk, easily, with friends who live around the world is very much a positive outcome from the internet. That and Wikipedia, which is a crowning human achievement – an almost complete, detailed encyclopedia that is well sourced and referenced, arguably more up to date than, say, the encyclopedia Britannica. And science papers – I would not like to go back to digging through a library.Lupe_evYes! From 8pm to 8am every day.yogainspainThe vital change is to make the directors of social media firms personally responsible for the content of everything their algorithms place in people’s feeds. If they are made to pay for all misinformation, fake news, harm caused they might clean up their systems.Aitku2We would miss fear and anxiety.SpringCrocusI just appreciated the sardonic wit of the questioner posting this particular question for discussion on … an internet site!Randomusername222Search engines, including voice – activated and AI driven, are invaluable as cognitive decay kicks in. Speaking for a friend …SimonMaxwell001The only groups of people capable of doing that on a wide enough scale are governments, and, well, would you trust them to do that for the right reasons?The internet is not the problem, it’s everything that a small handful of extremely powerful tech companies decided was a necessity after the internet came about.tildarInternet no, social media yes.lexicon_mistressThe whole point of the internet is to avoid being turned off and to interpret attempts to interfere with it as damage and route around them. It’s even funnier when people talk about turning off AI. AI is much more likely to switch us offCorkerryThe internet is garbage and has made everything worse but I have made a shitload of money from it.ManleyWe should at least delete everything and start again, this time with much stricter rules on anonymity and porn.JustdreamingWithout the internet I wouldn’t know that 5G mobile signals caused Covid-19.CorkerryThe internet has turned fringe belief into mainstream politics and policy – from authoritarianism to vaccines. No, that’s enabled by “the internet”, but it’s not what the internet “is”, or anywhere near everything networking is capable of.leadballoonA major issue with the internet in its current form is accountability. Anonymity and pseudonimity predominate and are exploited. You can’t tell the difference between a malign foreign actor and someone with a genuine grievance. Clickbait content is picked and amplified by the media giving it false weight. Frustratingly, the tools that ensure accountability and prevent anonymity have been around for over 20 years but technology companies have not implemented them. We are paying the price for the liberal and paranoid – albeit well-intentioned – philosophies on which the internet was founded which allow identity to be obfuscated. The ironic situation we now find ourselves means that criminals can communicate securely -using the said technologies- while keeping their identities secret. This wasn’t part of the plan but it could still be corrected. The question is, who is prepared to pick up the bill?ChrisGilbertI spend all Sunday alone in my flat. I quite like looking at daft cat pics on t’internet to cheer me up or phoning family and friends in another country using Messenger or WhatsApp. I’d be even more isolated than I am now without it.scouser58I have been steadily decreasing my time online and my life is becoming richer and quieter. I listen to CDs, read books and just spend more time paying attention to the world around me. This can only be described as liberating.Was alarmed to read that mail service is becoming more limited in some places. This takes away our ability to have a choice in how we conduct business and how we reach out to others via post. The internet must not become the only way to communicate!LauraWI would love a discussion of how exactly the AI economy will work without workers. (I’ve unplugged everything but the internet – no apps, no streaming services, no social media – just internet.)irisbjonesTrump only has to sign a directive in the interests of “national security” that temporarily suspends US cloud infrastructure companies such as Alphabet, AWS, Azure, Cloudflare, etc, from supplying their services to a country, then sit back as they suffer economic collapse.wyrcommunityCan you really fake it to make it?Read moreLying in bed on a Sunday morning reading the (online) Guardian on the other side of the world. I would miss that.BizzythegingeI had no idea what the “internet” was until I Googled it. It sounds awful!huw1964If we did, I’d miss sending and receiving emails, Wikipedia, Google images, masterpieces of world art, searching poems, song lyrics, immortal quotations and old movies, YouTube music, translating other languages into english, daily news, critics of rubbish and conspiracies, and Notes & Queries, which asks all the right questions. I would definitely not miss insolent and boastful social media, never-ending podcasts and smartphone selfies.RPOrlando, by emailIf the internet were to crash permanently tomorrow, I wouldn’t be upset. I may be an old fart but to me the pre internet days were better. It was so nice when you could look up someone’s number in a phone book and give them a call and they would actually answer. That doesn’t happen any more. Now if you want to talk to someone you have to have the inside scoop on their number and then send them a text to tell them that at such and such time you will be giving them a call and then, just maybe, they will actually answer. This isn’t progress, this is just plain weird.I’m a senior and it would be unwise to just run off to a cabin in the woods but honestly, I might as well be a hermit in the woods with how the world has become. I’m fed up with how things are and where we seem to be heading. Things aren’t improving, they are getting worse and the internet is largely to blame.TimMcGiffin, by emailShould we turn the internet off?Read moreYes! I speak as a child of the 90s, in my view everything was better back then and it got worse down to many factors but the biggest one would be the internet. Fake news is a problem, social media takes dumb people, makes them dumber and spreads its ignorance faster than any pandemic.Bring back Argos catalogues, teletext, the cinema listings in the local paper, bring back the local paper at an affordable price, staffed by humans, not AI bots. Bring back magazines (though obviously improve paper recycling infrastructure). You can’t hack a checkbook from Moscow, you can’t destabilise a country using a ham radio halfway round the world. It’s time to stop viewing hi-tech as the way forward.Martin Meyer, by emailI can’t think of anything about life that the internet has made better except for free international calling. Different yes, but not better. Of course I can remember a time before the internet which a large percentage of the population cannot, so they have nothing with which to compare it. I’d be more than happy to go back to the 1980’s, without Margaret Thatcher of course.Sam McGregor, Bideford, DevonIf the internet were shut off tomorrow, there might be more jobs, more friction, more gatekeepers. But the snake oil salesmen would remain. They always have.The question isn’t whether we should turn the internet off. The tool is not the disease. Our refusal to cultivate discernment is.Lynette Seebohm, by emailExplore more on these topicsLife and styleNotes and queriesDigital mediaSmartphonesMobile phones (Money)Mobile phones (Technology)TelecomsfeaturesShareReuse this content
