Content: Brahim Díaz settles Morocco’s last-16 tie against Tanzania with his fourth goal of the 2025 tournament.Photograph: Amr Abdallah Dalsh/ReutersView image in fullscreenBrahim Díaz settles Morocco’s last-16 tie against Tanzania with his fourth goal of the 2025 tournament.Photograph: Amr Abdallah Dalsh/ReutersAfrica Cup of Nations 2025Brahim Díaz fires winner as Afcon hosts Morocco survive scare against TanzaniaLast 16: Morocco 1-0 Tanzania (Brahim 64)Cameroon await in last eight after beating South AfricaReutersSun 4 Jan 2026 16.59 ESTFirst published on Sun 4 Jan 2026 14.46 ESTShareBrahim Díaz scored his fourth goal for Morocco at the 2025 Africa Cup of Nations to put the hosts into the quarter-finals witha nervous 1-0 victory over Tanzaniain Rabat.Morocco dominated possession but Tanzania had opportunities to cause a huge shock, and it took a fine strike from Brahim to book a place in the last eight.Paranoia and Mali get the better of timid, tetchy TunisiaRead moreThe Morocco captain, Achraf Hakimi, fed Brahim on the right side of the box on 64 minutes and the Real Madrid winger worked his way to the byline, before firing into the goal from a tight angle when most expected a cross.Walid Regragui’s side spurned several other chances but were fortunate that Tanzania were wasteful too, with Simon Msuva and Feisal Salum missing gilt-edged opportunities for the east Africans, who qualified for the last 16 as one of the four best third-placed sides despite failing to win any of their group games.It was a far from vintage performance from the home side, who have yet to click into top gear at the tournament but did enough to keep their campaign on track. “The competition is hotting up and we faced our toughest opponent in this Tanzania team,” Brahim said.“Not everything worked, we know that, but fortunately we managed to secure our qualification [to the next round],” Brahim, who is now the tournament’s top scorer, added. “Now, we are going back to work to be fully ready for the quarter-finals.”View image in fullscreenFeisal Salum misses an opportunity for Tanzania.Photograph: Jalal Morchidi/EPATanzania had an excellent early opportunity when Msuva had an open goal to head into, but he could only steer his effort well wide. Morocco then had the ball in the back of the net from Ismael Saibari’s header, but he was narrowly offside. Ayoub El Kaabi then missed two chances to score as the hosts grew frustrated.The underdogs should have been ahead on 55 minutes as the Morocco goalkeeper Yassine Bounou could only parry a long-range shot and the ball fell to Salum, who blasted over the crossbar from 10 metres with the goal gaping. Hakimi then crashed a free-kick against the frame of the goal, before Brahim finally made the breakthrough.Cameroonawait in the quarter-finals having scored a goal in either half to see offSouth Africa2-1. The five-time winners proved too strong as they kept on course for Afcon success to make up for their failure to qualify for this year’s World Cup in North America.Goals from Junior Tchamadeu and the teenage striker Christian Kofane ensured victory for the Indomitable Lions, although they had to fight off a late comeback as South Africa pulled one back through the substitute Evidence Makgopa with two minutes to play.Explore more on these topicsAfrica Cup of Nations 2025Morocco football teamTanzania football teamSouth Africa football teamCameroon football teamAfrica Cup of NationsnewsShareReuse this content

title: Thanasi Kokkinakis and Nick Kyrgios make emotional doubles comeback with win in Brisbane | Tennis | The Guardian
description: ‘Special Ks’ reunite for 5-7 6-4 10-8 defeat of Matt Ebden and Rajeev Ram after Kokkinakis had donor achilles tendon attached to shoulder in radical surgery
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: ‘Special Ks’ reunite for 5-7 6-4 10-8 defeat of Matt Ebden and Rajeev Ram after Kokkinakis had donor achilles tendon attached to shoulder in radical surgery
Content: Nick Kyrgios and Thanasi Kokkinakis made a triumphant men’s doubles return at the Brisbane International after both suffering long injury layoffs.Photograph: William West/AFP/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenNick Kyrgios and Thanasi Kokkinakis made a triumphant men’s doubles return at the Brisbane International after both suffering long injury layoffs.Photograph: William West/AFP/Getty ImagesTennisThanasi Kokkinakis and Nick Kyrgios make emotional doubles comeback with win in Brisbane‘Special Ks’ reunite for 5-7 6-4 10-8 defeat of Matt Ebden and Rajeev RamKokkinakis had donor achilles tendon attached to shoulder in radical surgeryAustralian Associated PressSun 4 Jan 2026 17.46 ESTShareThanasi Kokkinakis’s tears after a doubles match told the story as the injury-plagued Australian won in his latest and most dramatic return to the sport alongside old friendNick Kyrgios.The 29-year-old hadn’t played in almost a year, after groundbreaking pectoral surgery that involved attaching a donor’s achilles tendon to his shoulder.Emma Raducanu ruled out of United Cup opener in false start to new seasonRead moreDespite early rust, Kokkinakis soon clicked, and he and Kyrgios were brilliant at times in a 5-7 6-4 10-8 defeat of elite doubles specialists Matt Ebden and Rajeev Ram at the Brisbane International on Sunday night.Kyrgios and Kokkinakis won the Australian Open doubles title together in 2022 but have endured injury struggles since, with Kokkinakis not playing since the pair’s withdrawal from the same event last January.“I’ve never really teared up after a doubles match,” Kokkinakis said of the moment he choked up in the on-court interview after their enthralling win.“But all I’ve gone through in the last 12 months … A lot of surgeons, doctors.”Kokkinakis boasts a win over Roger Federer and has threatened many times to make grand slam runs, only for injury to intervene and keep him to a career-high of 65 in the world.“I said I didn’t want to keep doing what I was doing,” he said. “Play one match, maybe have a big win, and then my arm was shot.“I said, ‘I don’t care if I don’t play again, because I’m not doing that again.’ It was almost like a tease of what I can do, then I just have to pull out.”View image in fullscreenThanasi Kokkinakis plays a shot during his men's doubles match with Nick Kyrgios in Brisbane.Photograph: William West/AFP/Getty ImagesHe encountered puzzled looks and hesitation in meeting with doctors and surgeons around the world, including Rafael Nadal’s specialist, before the decision was made to attach “a dead man’s achilles” to his shoulder.“There’s been days it’s been OK and others where I’ve thought, ‘There’s no chance I’m playing again,’” he said of his lonely, unique rehabilitation effort.“I don’t know what my future holds, but I’ve done everything I can do give myself a chance.”Will Carlos Alcaraz prosper after split with coach as new tennis season looms?Read moreKokkinakis said he was yet to hit top gear on serve but had surprised himself with his level of play, rifling forehand winners and producing a clutch reflex volley and a winning smash on match point to end the 92-minute tussle.He will return to singles at the Adelaide International next week while Kyrgios – back after three injury-hit years of his own – will play singles on Tuesday against Aleksandar Kovacevic.“I understand how emotional it can be,” Kyrgios said of the pair’s rehabilitation efforts. “People underestimate how much work goes into it.“We were really surprised with our level. It’s been a year … playing two of probably the best doubles players out there.“Who knows what this year could look like for us, doubles wise?”Explore more on these topicsTennisNick KyrgiosAustralia sportnewsShareReuse this content

title: Pep Guardiola rues Manchester City injury crisis after Gvardiol and Dias blow | Manchester City | The Guardian
description: Key defenders picked up knocks during the 1-1 draw against Chelsea, with the manager Pep Guardiola saying after: ‘I have concerns … We don’t have players’
Author: Jamie Jackson
Headline: Key defenders picked up knocks during the 1-1 draw against Chelsea, with the manager Pep Guardiola saying after: ‘I have concerns … We don’t have players’
Content: Josko Gvardiol (centre) was substituted in the 51st minute against Chelsea because of injury.Photograph: Adam Vaughan/EPAView image in fullscreenJosko Gvardiol (centre) was substituted in the 51st minute against Chelsea because of injury.Photograph: Adam Vaughan/EPAManchester CityPep Guardiola rues Manchester City injury crisis after Gvardiol and Dias blowKey defenders picked up knocks in draw with Chelsea‘Of course I have concerns … We don’t have players’Jamie Jacksonat the Etihad StadiumSun 4 Jan 2026 16.00 ESTLast modified on Sun 4 Jan 2026 16.23 ESTSharePep Guardiola said he is concerned about injuries picked up by key defenders Josko Gvardiol and Rúben Dias in the1-1 draw with Chelsea.Manchester City’s manager said he should know on Monday how serious the problems are. City have seven more games in January with John Stones, another of their centre-backs, already injured. Gvardiol was forced off after 51 minutes and Dias half an hour later.Fernández stuns Manchester City with late equaliser for managerless ChelseaRead moreGuardiola said: “[Gvardiol] doesn’t look good. I didn’t speak with the doctor – I should know tomorrow [Monday] about them.”Although Rodri made a first start since 5 October, the manager is unsure if the Spaniard will be able to face Brighton at the Etihad Stadium on Wednesday as he continues his return to first-team action. Nico González, Rodri’s deputy, is also an injury doubt after going off at half-time of the draw at Sunderland on New Year’s Day.Guardiola is also without the long-term injured Mateo Kovacic, another holding midfielder. Savinho is another doubt.Guardiola said: “We have a lot [of injuries]. John Stones is missing for I don’t know how many months. Rúben now will be out, Josko will be out. Nathan [Aké], always we know with Nathan he cannot play regularly. It’s the situation.“Stay strong and we will find a solution. The spirit is there and will be there. Of course I have concerns. Have you seen the bench today? Four players from the academy and now we will have more. We don’t have players.”Quick GuideHow do I sign up for sport breaking news alerts?ShowDownload the Guardian app from the iOS App Store on iPhone or the Google Play store on Android by searching for 'The Guardian'.If you already have the Guardian app, make sure you’re on the most recent version.In the Guardian app, tap the Profile settings button at the top right, then select Notifications.Turn on sport notifications.Was this helpful?Thank you for your feedback.City had led due through a Tijjani Reijnders strike just ahead of the break before Enzo Fernández’s late leveller. Regarding their title challenge, Guardiola said: “Wednesday is Brighton and we see – I don’t have a crystal ball to know what will happen.”While Liam Rosenior reportedly flew to London on Sunday for talks about becoming Chelsea’s new permanent No 1, the interim head coach, Calum McFarlane, said: “We are training tomorrow [Monday] so unless I am told otherwise I will be taking that session. My sole focus has been on this game. Until I am told otherwise I will lead the team. It was a great experience a great game to be a part of, really proud of the players and how they performed particularly second half, great occasion.”Explore more on these topicsManchester CityChelseanewsShareReuse this content

title: Watford ‘did not agree to postponement’ of Hull match 18 minutes before kick-off | Watford | The Guardian

Author: Guardian sport
Headline: Watford have strongly criticised the decision to call off their Championship match at Hull City 18 minutes before kick-off on Sunday
Content: Hull’s match against Watford was called off due to safety concerns over icy areas around the pitch.Photograph: Ian Lyall/ProSports/ShutterstockView image in fullscreenHull’s match against Watford was called off due to safety concerns over icy areas around the pitch.Photograph: Ian Lyall/ProSports/ShutterstockWatfordWatford ‘did not agree to postponement’ of Hull match 18 minutes before kick-offMatch at MKM Stadium called off due to safety concernsVisitors insist they ‘were ready and willing to play’PA Media andGuardian sportSun 4 Jan 2026 15.59 ESTLast modified on Sun 4 Jan 2026 16.15 ESTShareWatford have criticised the decision to call off theirChampionshipmatch at Hull 18 minutes before kick-off on Sunday – and have claimed they did not agree to the postponement.The referee, Anthony Backhouse, called the game off due to safety concerns over areas surrounding the pitch while the players were already warming up. The MKM Stadium clash was one of three second-tier fixtures to fall by the wayside due to frozen pitches, while 14 games across Leagues One and Two were also postponed.Championship roundup: leaders Coventry slip up again in thriller at BirminghamRead moreHull said in a statement that the postponement was “agreed by all parties”, butWatfordinsisted they had been prepared to play the game and that the decision was made without their consent.“We reiterate we were ready and willing to play after the pitch was passed fit by the referee,” Watford said in a statement. “We remain disappointed by the decision to postpone and by how the decision was reached. We did not agree to the postponement.”In an earlier post on X, the club said: “While player safety is paramount, we are really disappointed the game has been postponed as we were ready to play. The decision to postpone the fixture so close to kick-off is regrettable and we fully share the frustration of our supporters.”Hull’s statement said: “While the pitch was playable and had been passed by the referee, areas immediately surrounding the playing surface were deemed unsafe and the decision to postpone the game was agreed by all parties.“We fully understand the frustration of supporters regarding the timing of the decision,” the statement continued. “Every effort was made to fulfil the fixture, and we sincerely apologise for the inconvenience and disappointment caused.”Quick GuideEFL games hit by freezing weatherShowChampionshipHull City v WatfordPortsmouth v IpswichSheffield United v OxfordLeague OneDoncaster v LutonPort Vale v BarnsleyRotherham v MansfieldStevenage v Leyton OrientLeague TwoBarnet v CreweBarrow v Bristol RoversBromley v OldhamCambridge v GrimsbyColchester v AccringtonHarrogate v SwindonNewport v TranmereNotts County v GillinghamSalford v ShrewsburyWalsall v FleetwoodWas this helpful?Thank you for your feedback.Sheffield United’s Championship meeting with Oxford United and Portsmouth’s clash with Ipswich at Fratton Park were also called off. title: World ‘may not have time’ to prepare for AI safety risks, says leading researcher | AI (artificial intelligence) | The Guardian
description: AI safety expert David Dalrymple said rapid advances could outpace efforts to control powerful systems
Author: Dan Milmo
Headline: AI safety expert David Dalrymple said rapid advances could outpace efforts to control powerful systems
Content: Dalrymple said there was a gap in understanding between public sector and AI companies about the power of looming breakthroughs in the technology.Photograph: d3sign/GettyView image in fullscreenDalrymple said there was a gap in understanding between public sector and AI companies about the power of looming breakthroughs in the technology.Photograph: d3sign/GettyAI (artificial intelligence)World ‘may not have time’ to prepare for AI safety risks, says leading researcherAI safety expert David Dalrymple said rapid advances could outpace efforts to control powerful systemsDan MilmoGlobal technology editorSun 4 Jan 2026 09.00 ESTLast modified on Sun 4 Jan 2026 15.16 ESTShareThe world “may not have time” to prepare for thesafety risksposed by cutting-edge AI systems, according to a leading figure at the UK government’s scientific research agency.David Dalrymple, a programme director and AI safety expert at the Aria agency, told the Guardian people should be concerned about the growing capability of the technology.“I think we should be concerned about systems that can perform all of the functions that humans perform to get things done in the world, but better,” he said. “We will be outcompeted in all of the domains that we need to be dominant in, in order to maintain control of our civilisation, society and planet.”UK actors vote to refuse to be digitally scanned in pushback against AIRead moreDalrymple said there was a gap in understanding between the public sector and AI companies about the power of looming breakthroughs in the technology.“I would advise that things are moving really fast and we may not have time to get ahead of it from a safety perspective,” he said. “And it’s not science fiction to project that within five years most economically valuable tasks will be performed by machines at a higher level of quality and lower cost than by humans.”Dalrymple said governments should not assume that advanced systems are reliable. Aria is publicly funded but independent from the government and directs research funding. Dalrymple is developing systems to safeguard AI’s use in critical infrastructure such as energy networks.Third of UK citizens have used AI for emotional support, research revealsRead more“We can’t assume these systems are reliable. The science to do that is just not likely to materialise in time given the economic pressure. So the next best thing that we can do, which we may be able to do in time, is to control and mitigate the downsides,” he said.Describing the consequences of technological progress getting ahead of safety as a “destabilisation of security and economy”, Dalrymple said more technical work was needed on understanding and controlling the behaviours of advanced AI systems.“Progress can be framed as destabilising and it could actually be good, which is what a lot of people at the frontier are hoping. I am working to try to make things go better but it’s very high risk and human civilisation is on the whole sleep walking into this transition.”This month the UK government’s AI Security Institute (AISI) said the capabilities of advanced AI models were “improving rapidly” across all domains and the performance in some areas was doubling every eight months.Third of UK citizens have used AI for emotional support, research revealsRead moreLeading models can now complete apprentice-level tasks 50% of the time on average, up from approximately 10% of the time last year, according to the institute. AISI also found that the most advanced systems can autonomously complete tasks that would take a human expert over an hour.The institute also tested advanced models for self-replication, a key safety concern because it involves a system spreading copies of itself to other devices and becoming harder to control. The tests showed two cutting-edge models achieving success rates of more than 60%.However, AISI stressed that a worst-case scenario was unlikely in a day-to-day environment, saying any attempt at self-replication was “unlikely to succeed in real-world conditions”.Dalrymple believes that AI systems will be able to automate the equivalent of a full day of research and development work by late 2026, which will “result in a further acceleration of capabilities”, because the technology will be able to self-improve on the maths and computer science elements of AI development.Explore more on these topicsAI (artificial intelligence)ComputingnewsShareReuse this content

title: Battery electric cars will overtake diesels in Great Britain by 2030, analysis suggests | Automotive industry | The Guardian
description: London predicted to be the first UK city to go diesel-free, largely because of the ultra-low emission zone
Author: Jasper Jolly
Headline: London predicted to be the first UK city to go diesel-free, largely because of the ultra-low emission zone
Content: Battery electric cars made up only 4% of the cars on UK roads last year.Photograph: Alex Segre/AlamyView image in fullscreenBattery electric cars made up only 4% of the cars on UK roads last year.Photograph: Alex Segre/AlamyAutomotive industryBattery electric cars will overtake diesels in Great Britain by 2030, analysis suggestsLondon predicted to be the first UK city to go diesel-free, largely because of the ultra-low emission zoneJasper JollySun 4 Jan 2026 10.00 ESTLast modified on Sun 4 Jan 2026 15.16 ESTShareBattery electric cars are poised to overtake diesels on Great Britain’s roads by 2030, according to analysis that suggests London will be the first UK city to go diesel-free.The number of diesel cars on Great Britain’s roads in June had fallen to 9.9m in June last year, 21% below its peak of 12.4m vehicles, according to analysis by New AutoMotive, a thinktank focused on the transition to electric cars. Electric car sales are still growing rapidly, albeit moreslowly than manufacturers had expected.However, the transition to cleaner vans is lagging behind cars, and the number of diesel vans has continued to rise, to a record 4.4m.The UK went through a“dash for diesel”cars in the 2000s as the government granted them cheaper tax rates. Diesel engines tend to be more efficient than petrol engines, burning less fuel and producing less carbon dioxide.However, they also produce more nitrous oxides, which are harmful to health. In 2015 Volkswagen was found to have created software to cheat on emissions tests, kicking offthe “Dieselgate” scandal, costing it alone €30bn (£26bn) around the world in fines, compensation and legal costs. Analysis this year suggested the extra emissions from cheat devices from Volkswagen and other carmakers wereresponsible for thousands of deathsand cases of asthma.Sales of cars with diesel engines duly plummeted, to fewer than 100,000 in the first 11 months of 2025. However, it will take some time for the share of diesel cars on the road to diminish, as many cars bought during the peak years of diesels are only now being scrapped.Battery electric cars made up only 4% of the cars on UK roads last year, compared with 32% diesels and 58% that use petrol, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), a lobby group. The other 6% were hybrids, which mostly combine a smaller battery with a petrol engine.Graph showing that electric cars will overtake diesel ones on roads in Great Britain by 2030Nevertheless, the number of diesels should drop as older cars are scrapped, delivering benefits for towns and cities where particulates tend to be concentrated. That will also have a knock-on effect for filling stations, leading to many withdrawing diesel supplies.London is expected to be the first place in the UK where no diesel cars or vans are registered, largely because ofthe ultra-low emission zone (Ulez), which applies charges for more polluting non-compliant cars. Diesel numbers are also dropping rapidly in the central belt of Scotland, which contains Edinburgh and Glasgow, both of which have low-emission zones.View image in fullscreenThe ultra-low emission zone (Ulez) applies charges to more polluting non-compliant cars.Photograph: PA Images/Alamy“Ending the use of diesel is essential to clean up Britain’s choking cities,” said Ben Nelmes, the chief executive of New AutoMotive. “The UK is now rolling out electric cars at a rapid pace, and this is great news for everyone that enjoys clean air, quieter streets and really cheap running costs.“The UK imports billions of pounds of diesel every year, and we have been completely reliant on other countries to feed our thirst. Thankfully, we’re switching to electric cars at a rapid rate, and that will make the country cleaner and wealthier.”However, the analysis found that people in cities appeared to be selling their diesels to people in more rural areas.The report found that, while the number of diesel vans has risen over the past decade, the peak of new diesel van sales probably happened before the pandemic, meaning the numbers on roads will eventually fall.Matt Finch, an environmental policy expert who co-wrote the report, said the world was “leaving the diesel age”. He said: “No one is denying diesel hasn’t been useful, but it has had its day.”Explore more on these topicsAutomotive industryElectric, hybrid and low-emission carsAir pollutionPollutionGreenhouse gas emissionsEthical and green livingTravel and transportShareReuse this content

title: The cost of AI slop could cause a rethink that shakes the global economy in 2026 | Heather Stewart | The Guardian
description: Revenues may be rising rapidly, but not by nearly enough to cover the wild levels of investment under way
Author: Heather Stewart
Headline: Revenues may be rising rapidly, but not by nearly enough to cover the wild levels of investment under way
Content: The vast datacentres required are so expensive that many are financed by debt secured against future revenue.Photograph: Aleksei Gorodenkov/AlamyView image in fullscreenThe vast datacentres required are so expensive that many are financed by debt secured against future revenue.Photograph: Aleksei Gorodenkov/AlamyEconomics viewpointAI (artificial intelligence)The cost of AI slop could cause a rethink that shakes the global economy in 2026Heather StewartRevenues may be rising rapidly, but not by nearly enough to cover the wild levels of investment under waySun 4 Jan 2026 07.18 ESTLast modified on Sun 4 Jan 2026 12.41 ESTShareThe US dictionary Merriam-Webster’sword of the yearfor 2025 was “slop”, which it defines as “digital content of low quality that is produced, usually in quantity, by means of artificial intelligence”. The choice underlined the fact that while AI is being widely embraced, not least by corporate bosses keen to cut payroll costs, its downsides are also becoming obvious. In 2026, a reckoning with reality for AI represents a growing economic risk.Ed Zitron, the foul-mouthed figurehead of AI scepticism, argues pretty convincingly that, as things stand, the “unit economics” of the entire industry – the cost of servicing the requests of a single customer against the price companies are able to charge them –just don’t add up. In typically colourful language, he calls them “dogshit”.Revenues from AI are rising rapidly as more paying clients sign up but so far not by enough to cover the wild levels of investment under way: $400bn (£297bn) in 2025, with much more forecast in the next 12 months.Another vehement sceptic, Cory Doctorow, argues: “These companies are not profitable. They can’t be profitable. They keep the lights on by soaking up hundreds of billions of dollars in other people’s money and then lighting it on fire.”It’s not new for frontier businesses to be loss-making, sometimes for years. But moving into profitability tends to happen as costs fall. Each iteration of large language models (LLMs) has so far tended to be more expensive, burning up more data, energy and highly paid tech experts’ time.The vast datacentres required to train and run the models are so expensive to build and kit out that in many cases they are financed by debt, secured against future revenue.Recent analysis by Bloombergsuggested there had been $178.5bn of these datacentre credit deals in 2025 alone, with inexperienced new operators joining Wall Street firms in a “gold rush”.Yet the precious Nvidia chips with which the datacentres are equipped have a limited shelf life, potentially shorter than that of the loan agreements.As well as leverage – borrowing – the boom increasingly involves another bubble indicator: financial engineering, including the kinds ofcomplex, circular funding arrangementsthat carry ominous echoes of past corporate crashes.Believing generative AI will eventually produce enough revenue to match the colossal sums invested, relies – as in all bubbles – on telling big, dramatic stories about the scale of the transformation under way.So LLMs are not just brilliant tools for analysing and synthesising large amounts of information. They’re fast approaching “superintelligence”, as OpenAI’s chief executive, Sam Altman, has it; or about toreplace human friendships, according to Mark Zuckerberg.They certainly do seem to be replacing some unfortunate human employees in specific sectors. Brian Merchant, the author of Blood in the Machine, which compares the backlash against big tech to the Luddite rebellion of the 19th century,has assembled scores of first-hand testimoniesfrom writers, coders and marketers laid off in favour of AI-generated outputs.Yet many of them highlight the bland quality of the work being produced by their digital replacements, or worse, the risks at play when sensitive tasks are shifted outside human control.Indeed, the dangers of charging headlong into replacing human workers wholesale have become increasingly apparent in recent months.In the UK, the high courtissued a warning about lawyers’ use of AIafter two cases in which examples of completely fictitious case law were cited.Police officers in Heber City, Utah, learned tomanually check the work of a transcription toolthey were using to draft write-ups from bodycam footage after it mistakenly claimed an officer had turned into a frog. Disney’s The Princess and the Frog was playing in the background.Specific examples such as these fail to take into account the costs of what Merchant calls the “slop layer” of AI-generated content coursing through every online space, making it harder to identify what is real or true.Doctorow argues: “AI isn’t the bow-wave of ‘impending superintelligence’. Nor is it going to deliver ‘humanlike intelligence’. It’s a grab-bag of useful (sometimes very useful) tools that can sometimes make workers’ lives better, when workers get to decide how and when they’re used.”From the AI bubble to Fed fears: the global economic outlook for 2026Read moreThought of in this way, these technologies may still have significant productivity benefits, but perhaps not quite significant enough to justify today’s toppy valuations and the tsunami of investment under way.Any rethink would cause chaos on financial markets. As the Bank for International Settlements (BIS)recently pointed out, the “Magnificent Seven” tech stocks now account for 35% of the S&P500, up from 20% three years ago.A share price correction would have real-world consequences far beyond Silicon Valley, rippling out to hit retail investors on both sides of the Atlantic, Asian tech exporters and the lenders, including loosely regulated private equity firms, that bankrolled the sector’s expansion.In the UK, the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) estimatedin its budget forecasts, that a “global correction” scenario, in which UK and world stock prices fell 35% in the coming year, would knock 0.6% off the country’s GDP and cause a £16bn deterioration in the public finances.That would be relatively manageable compared with the 2008 global financial crisis, in which UK institutions were leading players. But it would still be keenly felt in an economy struggling to find its feet.So while it is perhaps understandable to anticipate a frisson of schadenfreude at the thought of big tech’s super-rich boss class being humbled, we’re all living in their world, and we would not escape the consequences.Explore more on these topicsAI (artificial intelligence)Economics viewpointEconomicsGlobal economyComputingnewsShareReuse this content

title: Readers reply: should we turn the internet off? | Life and style | The Guardian
description: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions ponders the online world – from what’s despicable to what’s indispensable
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions ponders the online world – from what’s despicable to what’s indispensable
Content: Was the old-tech world a better one? Who would turn back the clock?Photograph: Kirill Ikonnikov/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenWas the old-tech world a better one? Who would turn back the clock?Photograph: Kirill Ikonnikov/Getty ImagesNotes and queriesLife and styleReaders reply: should we turn the internet off?The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions ponders the online world – from what’s despicable to what’s indispensableThis week’s question: can you really fake it to make it?Sun 4 Jan 2026 09.00 ESTLast modified on Sun 4 Jan 2026 09.03 ESTShareThe internet has turned fringe belief into mainstream politics and policy – from authoritarianism to vaccines. With democracy itself threatened, is it time to go back to a previous world of landlines, letters and face to-face-contact, audiotapes and Ansaphones? What would we miss about the online world that is worth the risk to liberal culture and basic freedoms? Should we turn the internet off?Mees Visser, Groningen, the NetherlandsSend new questions tonq@theguardian.com.Readers reply“I can’t let you do that Dave.”LandofsanderYes. We did just fine before it came along.Michael York, by emailBit late now.GoldgreenReading a newspaper from around the world. I am about to do my grocery shopping online. I am messaging family on the other side of the Atlantic. And you want me to turn that off? The problem isn’t the internet, it’s the people.1EloiseAccording to Google’s AI Overview: “Come and have a go if you think you’re hard enough.”EddieChorepostWithout Google Maps I would probably still be walking in circles in the middle of Epping Forest.1AngryManThanks to Google maps, Iamwalking in circles in the middle of Epping Forest!!Doomxsfsddgvhyt)I won’t be the first to point out what the internet has offered to disabled people. It’s a place where someone I know, who finds speaking nearly impossible due to physical challenges, can be fluent, authoritative and, most importantly, properly listened to at last. And that’s just one example. It’s not for me or anyone else to take that away. I actually hate web 2.0 with a passion and for any number of reasons, but I can’t refute this point, nor would I seek to.AsureaHonestly, without the internet I would be isolated and alone. I have a conservative family and am in the closet and queer and trans. With the internet my world finally expanded and I finally became free. I learned about myself and became happy and at peace. I met my most important person after a lifetime of difficulty connecting to people and I found things I loved that changed me. The internet has done a lot of harm, yes, but it’s not black and white and has been a lifeline for queer and disabled folk such as myself. I am so grateful for the connection and friendship I found thanks to the internet.Kati777The internet itself is a magnificent technological achievement, not a moral failure. It has democratised access to knowledge, lowered barriers to publishing, connected marginal voices and transformed education, science and culture in ways that are hard to overstate.The problem is not “the internet” so much as the concentration of power in a handful of social media platforms that algorithmically amplify outrage, misinformation and fringe belief while disclaiming responsibility for the consequences.Most of the damage could be addressed by treating these companies as accountable intermediaries rather than neutral pipes: enforcing transparency around amplification, meaningful liability for harm, and standards closer to those long applied to publishers and broadcasters.Rolling back to landlines and letters would mean losing real, hard-won freedoms. The challenge is not to abandon the online world, but to civilise it.littlewasterPlease God yes. However nice and convenient it is to book a train ticket or transfer money from my bank account, none of it compensates for the breakdown in society which is occurring because of what is now a malignant online world.Kirsty McNally, by emailI don’t know anybody who thinks society has improved in the last 30 years. I miss how fun and open-minded we used to be, and I miss being engaged with the real world, in all my time awake on this planet. Is there any chance of this actually happening? I hope so.Peter Rizzo, by emailShould we turn radio off? Should we turn newspapers off? Should we turn the printing press off? And books? Should we turn off writing on paper and drawing on cave walls? These questions were probably all raised by someone, not very long after those respective inventions escaped the control of their inventors. Each time, the previous elite lost control to the masses over information and discourse, history keeps repeating.Randomusername222No. We would miss that which is a deeply embedded and nearly indispensable need of humanity – connection. The internet allows us to quickly engage with other humans (around the planet!), which could be a lifesaver for those of us who cannot find community and acceptance in our immediate surroundings.In being able to share our experiences we can galvanise opinion to push for change (I’m thinking of the murder of George Floyd and following outrage, and also that in an era before the internet, it was through the sharing of images of brutalised peaceful protesters for racial equality in the American south that the country was shamed into reform).The internet enables sharing in a way unprecedented in human existence; it is this ability to join minds and hearts, sometimes across all known and artificial divisions that helps us find ourselves as individuals and communities, nations, and maybe one day as a planet.Henry Thorpe, by emailView image in fullscreenHappier days or a time of limited contact?Photograph: H Armstrong Roberts/ClassicStockThe internet is a communication medium, it is not the communication itself. Blaming “the internet” is like blaming the post office if you get a nasty letter. Turning off the internet would be like turning off mains electricity, or banning road transport other than horses.You can’t turn the clock back. There was no long-lost golden age.DopFnordMy job in IT heavily depends on it. Outside my job, I’ve deleted all social media apps from my phone. It’s been quite a liberating experience. That whole realm has been hijacked and I find it worrying how many people use it as their primary source of news and information. Thankfully this paper seems to be one of the few places of resistance.AyJayEmObviously it’s far too late to put the genie back in the lamp (perhaps a more accurate metaphor would be to unwet the mogwai), but I often find myself wishing we could roll things back to just before the invention of the smartphone. That way, we’d still have most of the benefits of the internet, but it would be contained within a bulky device that lived in the corner of a room in our homes and on our desks at work. We’d be able to turn our backs on it whenever we left the house or office, and we wouldn’t be obliged to carry it with us all the time (I know in most cases we’re not “obliged” to carry smartphones with us, but it takes tremendous strength of will to swim against the tide all the time, not to mention how difficult many organisations make it to do things offline).To me, that seems like a pretty good balance between enjoying the advantages of the internet while preserving those priceless and eminently human aspects of our lives that the internet has done a great deal to damage, if not outright destroyed.SignedUpToWriteThisThe best option is to use the internet in moderation and never to switch off your brain.willemijnheidemanThere is nothing on the internet that does not leave a digital footprint. Governments could so simply make “social media” responsible for the accuracy of what they publish, in the same way that a newspaper is responsible. If they can be sued, they will control the crazy people spouting lies. Make them responsible. Sanction their owners. China and Russia control the internet. It can be done.CynicalGeorgeIf anything, this article and comments has shown me that a huge amount of Guardian readers don’t know what the internet is or what aspects of modern life would be affected by “turning it off” (nearly everything, most likely from the power grid on up).unhelpfulThe question poses “the internet” as both the root cause of that which ails modern society and as the antithesis of liberalism and human freedom. This is, of course, leading the witness. The internet is not designed to respect geographical borders. Its technology is not free of political bias, though having been devised in the US that bias is towards the modern western conceptions of freedom that the writer holds in such high regard.The former GDR (East Germany) managed breathtaking levels of landline tapping and turning family members against one another. Conversations were frequently recorded. I do not see how a return to exclusively in-person contact, cassette tapes and landlines would intrinsically benefit those of us who value freedom.The internet is designed to be flexible, scalable and open at distance. The openness that doesn’t respect traditional notions of borders is the same openness that allows states to use marvellous technologies against their own populations, because here’s what governments understand: people want to feel connected to one another, those connections can threaten thestatus quo,ergothose connections need to be coralled and controlled.People and organisations campaigning for freedom have long gathered and communicated using the internet, predating by many years the modern “walled gardens” of social media. Those voices are still here and there and everywhere. Perhaps, if you step away from the noise of everyone shouting into the void, you’ll be able to discern them talking about running the world in a different way.DorkaliciousI have mobility issues, yet I’ve managed to do all my Christmas present shopping without leaving the house. I designed our Christmas card and uploaded the image to have it printed. We’ve just had a big food shop delivered.I can see via the NHS app on my phone that a prescription I requested has been approved and sent to our local pharmacy. The pharmacy will text me when it’s ready. We have several FaceTime sessions planned with family and friends around the world.I make a lot of use of the internet. It’s simply a question of using it wisely.snowybeachI was diagnosed as a type 1 diabetic in the early 80s and it was an extremely isolating experience. I knew no one else with the condition and just had to deal with things very much alone. It’s so much better now for newly diagnosed children to be able to connect to others in a similar position.AucklandCanaryView image in fullscreenEverything except the dial-up modem … the way things, recently, were.Photograph: Phiwath Jittamas/Getty ImagesPeople confuse the internet, which is a communication tool, with the various platforms, social media included, that use it. There are a lot of incredibly useful, practical things we do on the internet that benefit us. Not everything is a social media swamp, something we can choose to engage with, or not.The internet is still in its infancy, so we’re at the proverbial wild west stage of its development with a host of crazies, carpetbaggers, extremists and entrepreneurs allowed pretty free rein, so it can be grim. Governments and political campaigners have both tried to exploit this “freedom” and also failed to manage it, partly because they don’t understand it, so it’s a bit of a cesspool.Add the likes of all the tech bros, and it gets even worse.Not all bad though. Enshittification is now well recognised and people are getting pissed off with it. The days when everyone believed what they read are going fast, too, ironically hastened by the growth of AI slop and the likes of Trump and Musk. There’s more open criticism of such slop, and a lot more questioning of what’s the truth and what propaganda. The platforms are run by wealthy rightwingers but even now, much of the discussion is about obvious propaganda, fake AI-generated shopfronts and content. I believe social media has started to lose its attraction for many people, with people posting and engaging less.Almost half of young people would prefer a world without internet, UK study findsRead moreThe internet doesn’t need to be turned off, it just needs to be better managed and, on a personal level, used more carefully and responsibly. It needs to grow up.DJT1MillionWe’re in the corporate capture stage of the internet, which is why the user interface for most people now consists of checking the same four apps over and over again, and posting the same content from one of them on to one or more of the other three.Being online is no longer really enjoyable, it’s merely compulsive behaviour orcompulsoryfor participating in society – and is frequently actively annoying and frustrating in proportion to what you get out of it.In its first decade the possibilities of the internet seemed democratic and limitless. Now it’s just another plaything and control mechanism of the Oligarchy.Frank_LynnFor many people in the world, the internet provides one of the few opportunities for girls to study. I imagine that would be missed.GUsername1Technology destroys people and places. I’m rejecting it | Mark BoyleRead moreI was about 32 when the internet became widely used, and I often struggle to recall how on earth I found things out. I read more actual books from cover to cover and my attention span was longer. I now struggle to focus for longer than a few minutes. I once used the phone a lot to book things, which meant having to speak to actual people more. Friends reunited was fairly innocent fun, but then Facebook was born, Snapchat, TikTok … .ChrisPookThere are conceptually simple enough solutions to the stink of the internet sewer. One is to forbid anonymity. All uploads to incorporate a source address.The other would be an even greater boon – to tax ads.nosuchzoneNo. But democracies will need to learn how to address misinformation to challenge the mobocracy. Besides, it still has so many positive and benign uses. As a musician, I would miss the ease with which new skills can be learned and ideas shared. I’m sure others will find reasons of their own for not wanting to turn the clock back.fender64Maybe a world internet-free day might be doable as a way of reflection on being too dependent on it. I will never forget that day in April in Spain when all the electricity went off and one couldn’t access the internet. People were much nicer to each other and helped one another out. You couldn’t access the news without a transistor radio and that wasn’t a bad thing.DaveTrollI’m sure I’ve read about surgeons who have to do something rare being able to get live expert guidance by video call. That’s potentially life-saving.HummusexualMeta just suspended my Facebook account, probably for reporting too many hate groups. So I guess that means less internet for me.TatrabantQuality of life was much better before the internet. People had time for each other, it was possible to understand and fix machines, and convenience was not dependent on accepting endless nastiness, fraud, and fascist adventuring as a fact of life.Digital processes are useful for research but have proved a disaster for human communication and now fuel criminality faster than the ability of law enforcement to contain them. Pull the plug and let us learn to live again.ElephantmothIt was different, but whether it was better depended on circumstances. Those people around the world who now have access to some form of education thanks to internet access might disagree with [turning it off].middle24Without the internet, I’d not have my job (engineer), my bachelor’s and master’s degrees, would’ve found it much harder to find my apartment and roommate, and couldn’t do most of my shopping online so would need to take longer and more frequent trips just to shop since I’ve chosen a car-free lifestyle.But I’m also only on one social network: Reddit, which allows me to read and interact with others about just the topics I select. I only enable notifications for things that actually matter on my phone. I’m also among the minority not staring down at my phone on a bus or train, partly because it gives me motion sickness. I also rarely wear headphones while out, due to preferring to tune into my environment or let my mind wander.So I think the problem is not the internet itself but how we use it. Many fall into the trap of semi-passive consumption of media, allowing those on the other side of that content to disproportionally influence their ideas and behaviors. Were more people wise and kind in their usage of the internet, that’s what would make it better.fr33_th1nk3rAviation is so integrated with the internet that there would be chaos at airports. If you consider that shutting down aviation at the same time would be a good thing, just consider how much food comes in to the UK by air freight, and how much gets exported the same way (Scottish whisky and salmon). There’d be chaos.SocialismnowMake everyone use their real names online. You get a single email address and a single “internet-wide” user account. That will solve most of your problems right there.allanbabb(Replied to byBristolBoy: “Unless you are a dissident in, say, Russia or China, of course”, and byDauGiHyfryd:“I wonder if some of us will, in a year or two, be taken to task for our currently legal posts in the UK.”)My answer is a resounding no. Although there are some areas of the internet which have become walled gardens of algorithms, AI slop and advertising, there are so many other areas where the spirit of the early internet lives on. One example is the “indieweb” where people amateurishly code their own websites, making public whatever content they want rather than staying within the bounds of media companies.The rise of the ‘indieweb’ also includes the resurgence of the email newsletter (or RSS feed if you like). Instead of scrolling on infinite social media feeds, I get my brain going with some thoughtfully written blog posts in my inbox, introducing me to perspectives I would never have come across in the offline world. Long live the indieweb!accidentalusernameYeah go on – let’s see what happens. More shops on the high street, more money spent locally. More social cohesion, interaction and tolerance?ForfrocksakesGibbonsThe grass is always greener. As with all things, the key is balance. The internet is a tool. It’s up to us collectively to make the most out of the tools we have. Unfortunately, the people power of the internet is increasingly owned by the topmost shareholders.KromenoidDid you try turning it off and then turning it back on again?DeusPascitCorvosWhy stop there? Why not go back to tribal hunter gatherer existence and wearing animal skins?Face it. Every era has its challenges and this one is no different. Turning off the internet is throwing the baby out with the bath water.krutThe ability to talk, easily, with friends who live around the world is very much a positive outcome from the internet. That and Wikipedia, which is a crowning human achievement – an almost complete, detailed encyclopedia that is well sourced and referenced, arguably more up to date than, say, the encyclopedia Britannica. And science papers – I would not like to go back to digging through a library.Lupe_evYes! From 8pm to 8am every day.yogainspainThe vital change is to make the directors of social media firms personally responsible for the content of everything their algorithms place in people’s feeds. If they are made to pay for all misinformation, fake news, harm caused they might clean up their systems.Aitku2We would miss fear and anxiety.SpringCrocusI just appreciated the sardonic wit of the questioner posting this particular question for discussion on … an internet site!Randomusername222Search engines, including voice – activated and AI driven, are invaluable as cognitive decay kicks in. Speaking for a friend …SimonMaxwell001The only groups of people capable of doing that on a wide enough scale are governments, and, well, would you trust them to do that for the right reasons?The internet is not the problem, it’s everything that a small handful of extremely powerful tech companies decided was a necessity after the internet came about.tildarInternet no, social media yes.lexicon_mistressThe whole point of the internet is to avoid being turned off and to interpret attempts to interfere with it as damage and route around them. It’s even funnier when people talk about turning off AI. AI is much more likely to switch us offCorkerryThe internet is garbage and has made everything worse but I have made a shitload of money from it.ManleyWe should at least delete everything and start again, this time with much stricter rules on anonymity and porn.JustdreamingWithout the internet I wouldn’t know that 5G mobile signals caused Covid-19.CorkerryThe internet has turned fringe belief into mainstream politics and policy – from authoritarianism to vaccines. No, that’s enabled by “the internet”, but it’s not what the internet “is”, or anywhere near everything networking is capable of.leadballoonA major issue with the internet in its current form is accountability. Anonymity and pseudonimity predominate and are exploited. You can’t tell the difference between a malign foreign actor and someone with a genuine grievance. Clickbait content is picked and amplified by the media giving it false weight. Frustratingly, the tools that ensure accountability and prevent anonymity have been around for over 20 years but technology companies have not implemented them. We are paying the price for the liberal and paranoid – albeit well-intentioned – philosophies on which the internet was founded which allow identity to be obfuscated. The ironic situation we now find ourselves means that criminals can communicate securely -using the said technologies- while keeping their identities secret. This wasn’t part of the plan but it could still be corrected. The question is, who is prepared to pick up the bill?ChrisGilbertI spend all Sunday alone in my flat. I quite like looking at daft cat pics on t’internet to cheer me up or phoning family and friends in another country using Messenger or WhatsApp. I’d be even more isolated than I am now without it.scouser58I have been steadily decreasing my time online and my life is becoming richer and quieter. I listen to CDs, read books and just spend more time paying attention to the world around me. This can only be described as liberating.Was alarmed to read that mail service is becoming more limited in some places. This takes away our ability to have a choice in how we conduct business and how we reach out to others via post. The internet must not become the only way to communicate!LauraWI would love a discussion of how exactly the AI economy will work without workers. (I’ve unplugged everything but the internet – no apps, no streaming services, no social media – just internet.)irisbjonesTrump only has to sign a directive in the interests of “national security” that temporarily suspends US cloud infrastructure companies such as Alphabet, AWS, Azure, Cloudflare, etc, from supplying their services to a country, then sit back as they suffer economic collapse.wyrcommunityCan you really fake it to make it?Read moreLying in bed on a Sunday morning reading the (online) Guardian on the other side of the world. I would miss that.BizzythegingeI had no idea what the “internet” was until I Googled it. It sounds awful!huw1964If we did, I’d miss sending and receiving emails, Wikipedia, Google images, masterpieces of world art, searching poems, song lyrics, immortal quotations and old movies, YouTube music, translating other languages into english, daily news, critics of rubbish and conspiracies, and Notes & Queries, which asks all the right questions. I would definitely not miss insolent and boastful social media, never-ending podcasts and smartphone selfies.RPOrlando, by emailIf the internet were to crash permanently tomorrow, I wouldn’t be upset. I may be an old fart but to me the pre internet days were better. It was so nice when you could look up someone’s number in a phone book and give them a call and they would actually answer. That doesn’t happen any more. Now if you want to talk to someone you have to have the inside scoop on their number and then send them a text to tell them that at such and such time you will be giving them a call and then, just maybe, they will actually answer. This isn’t progress, this is just plain weird.I’m a senior and it would be unwise to just run off to a cabin in the woods but honestly, I might as well be a hermit in the woods with how the world has become. I’m fed up with how things are and where we seem to be heading. Things aren’t improving, they are getting worse and the internet is largely to blame.TimMcGiffin, by emailShould we turn the internet off?Read moreYes! I speak as a child of the 90s, in my view everything was better back then and it got worse down to many factors but the biggest one would be the internet. Fake news is a problem, social media takes dumb people, makes them dumber and spreads its ignorance faster than any pandemic.Bring back Argos catalogues, teletext, the cinema listings in the local paper, bring back the local paper at an affordable price, staffed by humans, not AI bots. Bring back magazines (though obviously improve paper recycling infrastructure). You can’t hack a checkbook from Moscow, you can’t destabilise a country using a ham radio halfway round the world. It’s time to stop viewing hi-tech as the way forward.Martin Meyer, by emailI can’t think of anything about life that the internet has made better except for free international calling. Different yes, but not better. Of course I can remember a time before the internet which a large percentage of the population cannot, so they have nothing with which to compare it. I’d be more than happy to go back to the 1980’s, without Margaret Thatcher of course.Sam McGregor, Bideford, DevonIf the internet were shut off tomorrow, there might be more jobs, more friction, more gatekeepers. But the snake oil salesmen would remain. They always have.The question isn’t whether we should turn the internet off. The tool is not the disease. Our refusal to cultivate discernment is.Lynette Seebohm, by emailExplore more on these topicsLife and styleNotes and queriesDigital mediaSmartphonesMobile phones (Money)Mobile phones (Technology)TelecomsfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Digital wallet fraud: how your bank card can be stolen without it leaving your wallet | Banks and building societies | The Guardian
description: Fraudsters use phishing to steal card details, which fund a spending spree using Apple Pay or Google Pay
Author: Shane Hickey
Headline: Fraudsters use phishing to steal card details, which fund a spending spree using Apple Pay or Google Pay
Content: Once a card has been added to a digital wallet such as Apple Pay or Google Pay, the fraudsters buy electronics and designer goods that can be quickly resold.Photograph: Koshiro K/AlamyView image in fullscreenOnce a card has been added to a digital wallet such as Apple Pay or Google Pay, the fraudsters buy electronics and designer goods that can be quickly resold.Photograph: Koshiro K/AlamyScam watchBanks and building societiesDigital wallet fraud: how your bank card can be stolen without it leaving your walletFraudsters use phishing to steal card details, which fund a spending spree using Apple Pay or Google PayShane HickeySun 4 Jan 2026 02.00 ESTLast modified on Sun 4 Jan 2026 02.02 ESTShareYou get a call from your bank and the informed voice asks to you to confirm the personal details they have on file, which you do. You are then asked whether you bought something at an electrical retailer recently for £120 and spent £235 in Birmingham, but neither transaction rings true.The caller tells you they have blocked the payments but they must now secure your account, and say they will send you a notification to approve, or a code to pass on to them. You feel under pressure to protect your money, so you do what is asked.Unfortunately, the person at the other end of the phone is not your bank but a criminal, and they have added your payment card to a digital wallet on one of their many smartphones. At some stage, your account will be emptied by purchases of expensive phones or designer clothes, which will then be sold on.Banks have seen an increase in the number of attempts to exploit victims using theelaborate digital wallet fraudand have introduced new security measures to counter the threat.Danai Antoniou, the chief scientist at Gradient Labs, a financial services AI company, says the approach from criminals can appear harmless as the victim is not being asked to move money.“This is why most people don’t question it. If the notification says ‘never share this with anyone’ (or similar), they will pre-emptively mention it to the customer that this is a routine comment that comes with every notification – which is true, customers do become immune to warnings if they get warnings frequently,” she says.“Victims often describe feeling panicked and pressured during the call, being told their account is under attack, or that their money is at risk. In that heightened emotional state, approving a notification feels like the responsible thing to do. The victim believes they’re protecting their account, when, in reality, they’re handing over the keys.”Santander says that digital wallet fraud was the second biggest reason for card scam losses last year, while HSBC has reported an increase over the past 18 months.UK Finance, the banking trade body, says that the number of attempts has surged, in part because security systems have prevented criminals being successful, forcing them to make more attacks.What the scam looks likeThe fraud can start with phishing where the victim provides personal and bank details after a text message that promises, for example, a winter fuel allowance payment, or an offer for cheap products on social media.After a few weeks, enough time for the victim to forget about supplying details, the fraudster will contact them, claiming to be from their bank. They will know which bank because of the details already supplied by the victim.They may ask the victim to confirm the address, or postcode, they have on file, in order to portray legitimacy. The criminal will then ask about some transactions, all fabricated, and when the victim says they don’t recognise them, the criminal will claim they have been stopped, and more measures must be taken to secure the account. They will say that a notification is on the way, and the victim should approve it to secure the account.View image in fullscreenThe scammers use text messages to secure victims’ personal and bank details.Photograph: DCPhoto/Alamy“The notification the customer receives is entirely legitimate, as it’s the genuine notification your bank sends when a new Apple Pay orGooglePay card is being added to a device, or the bank may send you a code via text, or in the app. They have just added your card into their Apple Pay or Google Pay and you are now receiving a text, or a notification, to approve it,” Antoniou says.From there, the criminals can act quickly and empty the account of the victim. “They drain accounts at high-value merchants, such as tech stores and fashion retailers. The appeal is simple: electronics and designer goods can be quickly resold on the secondary market with minimal loss of profit during the money-laundering process,” she adds.What to doBanks don’t need your help to protect your account: they have systems in place to freeze and block accounts if needed. “Never trust anyone who calls you from your bank unless you arranged that phone call in advance. If somebody calls, tell them you will call the bank back yourself,” Antoniou says. And don’t use a number they give you: search on the web for the bank’s phone number, or use the one on the back of your physical debit or credit card.Nationwide warns people to be aware of what any one-time passcodes they receive are being used for.HSBC says it has put in new security measures to counter the threat of wallet fraud and more would be coming this year. “We are regularly reminding customers not to give out their details, such as one-time passcodes, and to treat them as carefully as you would your pin,” it adds.UK Finance says: “Set up bank alerts in your app, and check your transactions regularly so you know about any suspicious transactions as soon as possible.“If you think you’ve fallen for a scam it’s important to contact your bank immediately and report it to Report Fraud.”Apple says it is not responsible for approving a card for inclusion in the wallet, but that it gives banks information that they can use to combat fraud.Google did not respond to a request for comment.Explore more on these topicsBanks and building societiesScam watchScamsConsumer affairsBankingAppleGooglefeaturesShareReuse this content

title: The Guardian view on the US seizure of Maduro: Trump has turned the world’s superpower into a rogue state | Editorial | The Guardian
description: Editorial: The illegal abduction of Venezuela’s president, and threat to ‘run’ his country, is a dangerous act. Its repercussions will be felt far beyond the region
Author: Editorial
Headline: Editorial: The illegal abduction of Venezuela’s president, and threat to ‘run’ his country, is a dangerous act. Its repercussions will be felt far beyond the region
Content: Donald Trump monitors US military operations in Venezuela, 3 January.Photograph: Molly Riley/APView image in fullscreenDonald Trump monitors US military operations in Venezuela, 3 January.Photograph: Molly Riley/APOpinionUS foreign policyThe Guardian view on the US seizure of Maduro: Trump has turned the world’s superpower into a rogue stateEditorialThe illegal abduction of Venezuela’s president, and threat to ‘run’ his country, is a dangerous act. Its repercussions will be felt far beyond the regionSun 4 Jan 2026 13.11 ESTLast modified on Sun 4 Jan 2026 15.16 ESTShareAmid the immense confusion surrounding the USstrikeson Venezuela, the seizure of the president, Nicolás Maduro, and Donald Trump’s announcement that the US will “run” the country and“take back the oil”, one thing is clear – they set a truly chilling precedent. The US has agrim historyof interference, invasion and occupation in the region, but the early hours of Saturday saw its first major military attack on South American land. “American dominance in the western hemisphere will never be questioned again,” Mr Trump declared. The decision to unilaterally attack another country and abduct its leader – days after hepublicly sought an off-ramp– has still wider repercussions. It should alarm us all.Venezuelans have endured a repressive, kleptocratic and incompetent regime under Mr Maduro, widely believed to have stolen the last election. They now face profound uncertainty at best. Mr Trump has suggested thatMr Maduro’s deputy, Delcy Rodríguez, would follow US instructions, and dismissed the rightwing opposition leader and Nobel prize-winner María Corina Machado as a plausible replacement. But Ms Rodríguez, now interim president, has so farstruck a defiant tone– and other parts of the decapitated regime are more hardline.A man who won power promising to abandon foreign wars now says he is “not afraid of boots on the ground”. Rebranding the Department of Defense as the Department of War was more than posturing. He does not see the world’s superpower as policeman; he is turning it into a rogue state. He believes the US’s might allows it to do as it wishes with minimal cost: witness the strikes on Nigeria, on Iran’s nuclear facilities and elsewhere. He promises that Venezuelan oil means this latest episode “won’t cost us a penny”.George W Bush invaded Iraq on a lie. But thisillegal attackcame withoutUN resolutions of any kindor congressional approval; Democrats were not even informed and say they were actively misled in briefings. Mr Trump doesn’t seek to bend international norms, but to destroy them. Put aside the message this sends to Vladimir Putin, Xi Jinping and others, and ask where the US itself is heading. While the raid reportedly killed 40 Venezuelans, including civilians, no US personnel died. Mr Trump’s growing sense of invincibility will surely embolden further adventurism. He has not ruled out military action overGreenlandandtold Fox News: “Something is going to have to be done with Mexico.”No one buys the pretext that this is about drugs. Venezuela is only a minor conduit for cocaine; Mr Trump recentlypardoned the former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernándezfor drugs and weapons crimes. And Mr Trump himself made it clear that he is driven by the lure of oil as well as machismo, the ideology of some in his administration, and the desire for glory as domestic popularity wanes.The global reaction, especially in Europe, has – with honourable exceptions – been shockingly muted. That’s not due to Mr Maduro’s sins, but fear of Mr Trump’s wrath. The strong reaction from the UN’s secretary general, António Guterres, was welcome, but this episode underscores the institution’s growing irrelevance. Mr Trump’s anti-interventionist domestic base could yet press him to turn attention back home – but soaring healthcare premiums, economic unhappiness and the Epstein files increase his appetite for distraction.We are not yet 12 months in to his four-year term. Sir Keir Starmer and others may regret it if they stay silent now, given what – and who – could be next.Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? title: The Guardian view on Zohran Mamdani’s task: a high-stakes test case for progressive ambition | Editorial | The Guardian
description: Editorial: New York’s new mayor will face headwinds as he attempts to carry out a programme of civic renewal. But his affordability agenda speaks to the times
Author: Editorial
Headline: Editorial: New York’s new mayor will face headwinds as he attempts to carry out a programme of civic renewal. But his affordability agenda speaks to the times
Content: Zohran Mamdani and his wife, Rama Duwaji, at his swearing-in ceremony in New York on 1 January.Photograph: Richard Swafford/ZUMA Press Wire/ShutterstockView image in fullscreenZohran Mamdani and his wife, Rama Duwaji, at his swearing-in ceremony in New York on 1 January.Photograph: Richard Swafford/ZUMA Press Wire/ShutterstockOpinionZohran MamdaniThe Guardian view on Zohran Mamdani’s task: a high-stakes test case for progressive ambitionEditorialNew York’s new mayor will face headwinds as he attempts to carry out a programme of civic renewal. But his affordability agenda speaks to the timesSun 4 Jan 2026 13.11 ESTLast modified on Sun 4 Jan 2026 17.58 ESTShareThe multiplefirstsachieved by New York’s new mayor, Zohran Mamdani, have been well chronicled: he is the first Muslim to occupy that role, the first south Asian and the first to be born in Africa. He is also the youngest mayor of the largest city in the United States for over a century, havingreceivedmore votes in November’s election than any candidate since the 1960s. And politically, he is probably the most leftwing incumbent of the office sinceFiorello La Guardiain the 1930s and 40s.Hardly surprising then, that Mr Mamdani’s extraordinary rise to prominence should be accompanied by high expectations and tense anticipation. At last Thursday’s inauguration ceremony, he promised to “govern expansively and audaciously”. Whether he succeeds in doing so will have considerable ramifications for progressive politics more widely.Pledgingto make New York “a city we can afford”, Mr Mamdani campaigned on plans to introduce free universal childcare, hugely increase the availability of cheaper housing, and generally reduce everyday costs of living for residents. In order to finance this programme, he has restated his intention to raise tax rates on the very wealthy, and on corporations. Linking the vision of a livable metropolis to a politics of redistribution, this approach has assembled a coalition of voters ranging from young renters to union members, migrants and the professional middle classes.Progressive parties around the world have taken note. The political dynamics of New York, the home of Wall Street and a global centre for the arts, are not straightforwardly generalisable. But the affordability agenda that delivered Mr Mamdani’s flagship success has also fuelled a political revival for Democrats instatessuch as New Jersey and Virginia. In Europe too, the centre-left has fared best when focusing relentlessly on improving everyday life for the less well-off. The surprisevictoryof the D66 party in the recent Dutch election, for example, was largely attributed to its apparent seriousness about addressing the Netherlands’ chronic housing shortage.Mr Mamdani thus finds himself a youthful trailblazer for a radical politics of civic renewal and inclusion that, if it works, could counter more generally the rise of the populist far right. Donald Trumppromiseda “blue-collar boom” when he was re-elected. He has insteadpresidedover a widening equality gap, in which the wealthy have disproportionately benefited from tax cuts and a soaring stock market. There is space here for a new working-class politics of the left. In that spirit, Mr Mamdani’s head of budget, Sherif Soliman, hasstatedthat New York needs to be a livable home not just for Wall Street bankers, but for “low-wage workers, be it in retail or healthcare”.Formidable headwinds await, not least federal funding negotiations with a hostile Mr Trump, and opposition to what – inhistoricalterms – would be modest tax rises for high-income earners. There will also need to be some skilful coalition-building, not least with the Democratic governor of New York state, Kathy Hochul, who haspreviouslyspoken out against the hikes. Nevertheless, the political courage shown by New York’s charismatic new mayor during his ascent to power suggests that, in the heartland of global capital, he has the ability to make a difference. In an era in which swathes of blue-collar voters continue to drift rightwards, the stakes are high indeed.Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? title: The government probably took too much of your paycheck this year – here’s how to get it back | Gene Marks | The Guardian
description: Trump’s tax bill carved out several areas for tipped workers and older adults, among others, to lower their tax bills
Author: Gene Marks
Headline: Trump’s tax bill carved out several areas for tipped workers and older adults, among others, to lower their tax bills
Content: Thanks to the government shutdown, the IRS didn’t have time to update W-2 wage reporting forms to reflect changes in the tax code.Photograph: Michael Bocchieri/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenThanks to the government shutdown, the IRS didn’t have time to update W-2 wage reporting forms to reflect changes in the tax code.Photograph: Michael Bocchieri/Getty ImagesUS small businessThe government probably took too much of your paycheck this year – here’s how to get it backGene MarksTrump’s tax bill carved out several areas for tipped workers and older adults, among others, to lower their tax billsSun 4 Jan 2026 10.00 ESTLast modified on Sun 4 Jan 2026 10.02 ESTShareUS taxpayers will have a “gigantic refund year in the first quarter” of 2026, the treasury secretary, Scott Bessent,recently saidin an interview.Given all the untruths that come out of the current administration, you wouldn’t be blamed if you don’t believe him. But you should. This year, there will be a significant amount of tax refunds. Why? Well, it’s nottariffcash. It’s because many people overpaid their taxes this year.For example, service workers who receive tips will be getting refunds. Thanks toDonald Trump’s One Big Beautiful Bill Act (OBBBA), a new provision allows them to deduct up to $25,000 per individual for any tipped income they received during the year. But I bet even when the bill passed, few changed their withholdings to reflect this deduction. If you’re part of that group, then it’s very likely you had too much withheld … and paid too much tax. When you file your 2025 return between now and 15 April – and take advantage of this deduction – you’ll find out you owed less taxes than you estimated. Hence the refund.AI is coming for young people’s office jobs. That’s good news for the construction industry | Gene MarksRead moreThe same goes for workers receiving overtime pay. There’s a new deduction that will allow individuals to deduct up to $12,500 of their overtime pay received in 2025 (it’s $25,000 for joint filers). Similarly for service workers, it’s a deduction you take when you file your 2025 returns. I’m betting if you received overtime during the year, your withholdings didn’t reflect that either. So you’ll probably be getting money back on the taxes you overpaid.There are caveats. State and local taxes may both still apply. Employment taxes – social security and Medicare – aren’t affected. Both deductions start to phase out if you make more than $150,000. Not all tipped workers are eligible (here’sa listto check). Thanks to the shutdown, the IRS didn’t have time to update W-2 wage reporting forms to reflect these changes. And employers weren’t given much guidance as to how to calculate these amounts.It’s not just people who received tips and overtime that have new tax benefitsFor example, did you know that your overtime wage eligible for the deduction would only be the differential between your normal hourly rate and your overtime rate? So if you got paid time and a half for overtime and your normal rate is $20 an hour, you would receive $30 an hour – but your deduction is on the $10 difference. I’m not sure all employers will do these calculations correctly, so be careful – any mistakes are the taxpayer’s responsibility.I’m as capitalist as they get but Medicare for all is the best hope for US healthcare | Gene MarksRead moreIt’s not just people who received tips and overtime that have new tax benefits.Older adults – subject to some limitations – will get an additional $6,000 deduction this year over and above their standard deduction. If you run a small business, you’ll receive higher deductions for first-year depreciation and research and development costs. If you haven’t taken advantage already, you can contribute more to a flexible savings account (which reduces your taxable income) and contribute up to $5,000 to a “Trump savings account” this year and annually, which, while not reducing your income, will allow your newborn to accrue earnings tax-free through the age of 18 and then withdraw the funds without penalty.These deductions aren’t one-offs. Which is why it’s important that if you get a refund this year, make sure to adjust your withholdings for 2026 to reflect your updated taxable income for the current year. This way, you can increase your net pay and put more money in your pocket during the year instead of waiting until you file your 2026 returns in 2027.There are many critics of the OBBBA and they legitimately argue that the bill has many downsides – increasing deficits, taking away critical benefits and reducing spending in needed areas are among the biggest. Those issues aside, the bill does include significant tax benefits for many, benefits that may hopefully make a difference to both consumers and the economy at large.The OBBBA is law. However you feel about it, take advantage. File your 2025 tax returns as soon as possible. Get your refund.
